header.title: The Scroll of Set
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Setianism, Organizational Guidelines

central_thesis: This issue of 'The Scroll of Set' serves as an internal communication for members of the Temple of Set, providing insights into the contemporary state of occultism in Australia, outlining legal and ethical guidelines for organizational publications, clarifying the criteria for 'Recognition' (advancement) within the Temple, and answering member questions on Setian terminology and calendrical systems. It reinforces the Temple's commitment to individual development and responsible communication.

structure_content.summary: This article by Leon Marvell I° describes the state of the 'occult revival' in Australia in 1976 as largely non-existent or misunderstood by the general public, associating occultism with trivialities like ouija boards and Tarot cards. It notes the clandestine nature of serious occult practice and the limited presence of specialized bookstores and groups. Despite this, it acknowledges two knowledgeable Australian occult scholars, Nevill Drury and Stephen Skinner, and discusses the prevalence of 'white-light' groups over more profound magical traditions, with some exceptions for Tantrism and witchcraft.

Margaret Wendall IV° provides comprehensive guidelines for all Temple of Set publications, distinguishing between general and local/regional newsletters. The section emphasizes adherence to the First Amendment, allowing diverse content from essays to artwork. Crucially, it details legal limitations concerning copyright law (explaining its purpose, registration, and proper notification), libel (defining and advising against malicious representations), and the use of 'four-letter words' or 'suggestive pictures' due to minor access. It also advises on respecting privacy when using photographs and provides guidance on newspaper clippings.

Michael Waters III° addresses the process of 'Recognition' within the Temple of Set. He clarifies that advancement in degrees (I°, II°, III°+) is not based on written steps, whim, or favoritism, but solely on an individual's demonstrated expertise, knowledge, experience, and ability. Recognition is granted by a III°+ Initiate not to bolster egos, but to enable the individual to apply their skills within a broader sphere of influence, emphasizing the responsibility and hard work that accompany higher degrees.

This section answers two questions posed by Setian Rudolph Garza. The first clarifies the Temple's dating system, explaining the use of 'BCE' (Before Common Era) and 'CE' (Common Era) as alternatives to 'BC' and 'AD' respectively, and introducing 'AS' (originally 'Age of Satan,' now 'Æon of Set') as the Temple's own calendar starting in 1966 AD. It also briefly discusses the historical context of the Gregorian and Julian calendars. The second question explains 'Xeper' as a Setian magical word, defined in 'The Book of Coming Forth by Night,' used as a meaningful letter closing among Setians to express a will for mutual advancement.

key_concepts.definition: An organization dedicated to Setian philosophy and practices, whose publications disseminate information and guidance to its members.
An individual who is by definition a superior being, whose advancement within the Temple is solely limited by their own ability and demonstrated expertise.

The process of advancing in degrees (e.g., I°, II°, III°+) within the Temple of Set, granted based on an individual's demonstrated expertise, knowledge, experience, and ability, rather than favoritism or written steps. It is intended to expand one's sphere of influence and responsibility.
A Setian magical word, fully defined in 'The Book of Coming Forth by Night,' which is used as a letter closing among Setians to express a will for the recipient's advancement and growth.

The dating system used by Setians, originally 'Age of Satan,' now 'Æon of Set,' with Year I corresponding to 1966 AD/CE. It is used alongside or instead of the Gregorian calendar for chronological reference.

The exclusive right of publication granted to an author or artist for a certain number of years, encompassing the right to issue, transfer, and protect a work from unauthorized use. Proper notice (©, year, name) is required for full legal protection.

Anything written, printed, or expressed by a sign or picture, containing representations maliciously made or published, tending to bring a person into contempt, or expose him to public hatred or derision. Truth is the only defense against libel.

practical_system.description: This document is not a manual for a specific magical system, but rather a periodical that outlines the organizational and philosophical framework within which Temple of Set members operate and communicate. It details a system for internal communication through various publications (Scroll of Set, regional/local newsletters) with strict guidelines on legal compliance (copyright, libel). It also describes the 'Recognition' system for member advancement, which is based on demonstrating individual expertise and ability, implying that practical magical work and self-development are core to a Setian's progress, even if the specific rituals or tools are not detailed here. The mention of 'Xeper' as a magical word from 'The Book of Coming Forth by Night' suggests an underlying magical philosophy that members are expected to embody and develop.

relevant_quotes.text: Down Under the "occult revival" is a corpse that is barely able to lift just one feeble finger. For you see, the occult in Australia is held in very little regard.

The few limitations expressed in this article not only protect others from us, but protect us equally from others. Just as we are prohibited from using others' copyrighted ideas or from libeling others, the same laws protect us against infringements of our rights.

Degrees within the Temple are not handed out to bolster egos. When an individual is Recognized, it is done in order that he may put his demonstrated expertise to use within a wider sphere of influence.

Xeper is a Setian magical word, fully defined in the Book of Coming Forth by Night. Many Setians feel that the concept referred to as Xeper is one they would will for other Setians, and the use as a closing of a letter began.

critical_analysis.relevance: This issue of 'The Scroll of Set' is highly relevant for understanding the foundational period and operational philosophy of the Temple of Set. It provides rare primary source material on the organization's self-definition, its early attempts to structure internal communication, and its practical considerations regarding legal compliance in publishing. For scholars of Western Esotericism and New Religious Movements, it offers a valuable snapshot of a significant occult order in its nascent years, contrasting its internal seriousness with external perceptions of occultism. The discussion of 'Recognition' illuminates the meritocratic and individualistic ethos central to Setian philosophy.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is active members of the Temple of Set, for whom the content provides essential organizational information, philosophical guidance, and practical advice on contributing to and engaging with the Temple's communication channels. A secondary audience includes academic researchers, historians of modern occultism, and practitioners interested in the historical development and internal workings of the Temple of Set, particularly its unique approach to magical advancement and organizational structure.
